Topological invariant for two-dimensional open systems

Jun-Hui Zheng â€ƒâ€ƒ Walter Hofstetter Institut fÃ¼r Theoretische Physik, Goethe-UniversitÃ¤t, 60438 Frankfurt/Main, Germany.
Abstract

We study the topology of two-dimensional open systems in terms of the Greenâ€™s function. The Ishikawa-Matsuyama formula for the integer topological invariant is applied in open systems, which indicates the number difference of gapless edge bands arising from the poles and zeros of the Greenâ€™s function. Meanwhile, we define another topological invariant via the single-particle density matrix, which works for general gapped systems and is equivalent to the former for the case of weak coupling to an environment. We also discuss two applications. For time-reversal-invariant insulators, the Z2subscriptğ‘2{Z}_{2} index can be expressed by the invariant of each spin subsystem. As a second application, we consider the proximity effect when an ordinary insulator is coupled to a topological insulator.

I Introduction

The study of the quantum Hall effect has led to the new classification paradigm of quantum phases based on topological propertiesâ€‰Thouless1982prl ; Wen1990prb ; Hasan2010rmp ; Qi2011rmp . The corresponding topological invariants have been constructed for various systems with interactionâ€‰Thouless1982prl ; Ishkawa1987npb ; Wang2010prl ; Gurarie2011prb ; Niu1985prb , with disorderâ€‰Niu1985prb , and with time-reversal symmetryâ€‰Kane2005prl ; Sheng2006prl ; Lee2008prl . For the noninteracting case, the topological index is given by the integral of the Berry curvature determined by single-particle wave functions of the systemâ€‰Thouless1982prl ; Wang2010prl . For the interacting case, it is more convenient to use the expression in terms of the single-particle Greenâ€™s functionâ€‰Ishkawa1987npb instead of the many-body wave functionâ€‰Niu1985prb . In combination with (dynamical) mean field theoryâ€‰Georges1996rmp , it is feasible to obtain the topological index by calculating multiple integrals of the interacting Greenâ€™s functionâ€‰Wang2012epl . Meanwhile, two new developments have allowed us to simplify the calculation: (1) the topological Hamiltonian method, which captures topological properties of the original interacting Hamiltonianâ€‰Wang2012prx , and (2) the quasiparticle Berry curvature method, where the Berry curvature is determined by the quasiparticle states if these states have a long lifetimeâ€‰Shindou2008prb .

However, all of these methods are valid only for closed quantum systems. A realistic system, inevitably, is coupled to an environment. Especially for the noninteracting case, the ground state of an open system is expected to be a reduced density matrix (a mixed state) rather than a pure state. An extension of the Berry phase to mixed states in one-dimensional systems Uhlmann1986 ; Nieuwenburg2014 and related observables (e.g., Thouless pumping) Linzner2016prb ; Bardyn2017 has been proposed. For two-dimensional (2D) systems, there are several different versions of topological invariants for a general density matrixâ€‰Diehl2011np ; Rivas2013prb ; Bardyn2013njp ; Huang2014prl ; Budich2015prb ; Grusdt2017 , and only one of them corresponds to the Uâ€‹(1)ğ‘ˆ1U(1) holonomyâ€‰Budich2015prb . To include interaction effects, like for closed systems, the best option is to express the topological invariant in terms of the Greenâ€™s function.

For a general system Ağ´A immersed in an environment Eğ¸E, the effective partition function can be obtained by integrating out the degree of freedom of Eğ¸E. The resulting effective action retains the Uâ€‹(1)ğ‘ˆ1U(1) symmetry 111 The effective action is invariant under the Uâ€‹(1)ğ‘ˆ1U(1) transformation cAâ†’eiâ€‹Î¸â€‹cAâ†’subscriptğ‘ğ´superscriptğ‘’ğ‘–ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ğ´c_{A}\rightarrow e^{i\theta}c_{A}, where cAsubscriptğ‘ğ´c_{A} is the Grassmann field. For the case of weak coupling to the environment, the relaxation time of density fluctuations is supposed to be short, so that the total particle number of subsystem Ağ´A is approximately conserved. On the other hand, in the thermodynamic limit, the fluctuations of the total particle number in system Ağ´A are also suppressed;, thus, the Uâ€‹(1)ğ‘ˆ1U(1) symmetry, at a certain timescale, is obtained. . Accordingly, the first Chern number of the system Ağ´A can be defined by the Ishikawa-Matsuyama formula,

The index (1) is a well-defined topological invariantâ€‰Qi2008prb iff there are neither poles nor zeros for GAâ€‹(ğ¤,iâ€‹Ï‰)subscriptğºğ´ğ¤ğ‘–ğœ”G_{A}(\mathbf{k},i\omega) for all ğ¤ğ¤\mathbf{k} and imaginary frequency iâ€‹Ï‰ğ‘–ğœ”i\omega.

We develop both the topological Hamiltonian method and the Berry curvature method to evaluate Eq.â€‰(1). The topological Hamiltonian gives an effective single-particle description of the open system. On the other hand, the Berry curvature method shows that for an open system, besides the bands determined by the poles of the Greenâ€™s function (energy spectrum), the â€œbandsâ€ Ï‰â€‹(ğ¤)ğœ”ğ¤\omega(\mathbf{k}) from the zeros (denoted as blind bands here), i.e., detâ€‹GAâ€‹(ğ¤,Ï‰â€‹(ğ¤))=0detsubscriptğºğ´ğ¤ğœ”ğ¤0\text{det}G_{A}(\mathbf{k},\omega(\mathbf{k}))=0, appear and contribute to the topological properties. The value of ChAsubscriptChğ´\text{Ch}_{A} indicates the number difference of gapless edge modes and gapless edge blind bands.

When the coupling to the environment becomes larger, the blind bands may cross the Fermi surface [Fig.1(c)], i.e., detâ€‹GAâ€‹(ğ¤,Ï‰=0)=0detsubscriptğºğ´ğ¤ğœ”00\text{det}G_{A}(\mathbf{k},\omega=0)=0 for some ğ¤ğ¤\mathbf{k}, and thus, ChAsubscriptChğ´\text{Ch}_{A} becomes ill defined even though the energy spectrum is still gapped. For a general gapped system, we propose a topological invariant IAsubscriptğ¼ğ´{I}_{A} based on the single-particle density matrix ÏAâ€‹(ğ¤)subscriptğœŒğ´ğ¤\rho_{A}(\mathbf{k}) with ÏAÏƒâ€‹Ïƒâ€²=âŸ¨cA,ğ¤â€‹Ïƒâ€²â€ â€‹cA,ğ¤â€‹ÏƒâŸ©superscriptsubscriptğœŒğ´ğœsuperscriptğœâ€²delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ´ğ¤superscriptğœâ€²â€ subscriptğ‘ğ´ğ¤ğœ\rho_{A}^{\sigma\sigma^{\prime}}=\langle c_{A,\mathbf{k}\sigma^{\prime}}^{\dagger}c_{A,\mathbf{k}\sigma}\rangle, which is equivalent to ChAsubscriptChğ´\text{Ch}_{A} when the system is weakly coupled to the environment. For a noninteracting system, there is a one-to-one correspondence between the density matrix and the entanglement Hamiltonianâ€‰Peschel2002 ; Fidkowski2010prl . Unlike the previous discussions of the relation between the entanglement spectrum (entropy) and topological properties of the full system (A+Eğ´ğ¸A+E)â€‰Kitaev2006prl ; Hsieh2014prl ; Chandran2014prl , we focus on the physical implication of the eigenstates of the density matrix for Ağ´A. The index IAsubscriptğ¼ğ´{I}_{A} [see Eq.â€‰(6) below] is determined by the Berry curvature of the dominant eigenstates of the density matrix ÏAâ€‹(ğ¤)subscriptğœŒğ´ğ¤\rho_{A}(\mathbf{k}), as proposed in Ref.â€‰Budich2015prb for noninteracting systems, giving the number of gapless edge modes for ÏAsubscriptğœŒğ´\rho_{A}.

This paper is organized as follows. In Sec. II, we show that the topological Hamiltonian is applicable for the case when GAâ€‹(ğ¤,iâ€‹Ï‰)subscriptğºğ´ğ¤ğ‘–ğœ”G_{A}(\mathbf{k},i\omega) has neither poles nor zeros. In Sec. III, we express the Chern number (1) through the Berry curvature of the bands of the energy spectrum and the blind bands. In Sec. IV, a density-matrix description of topological invariance is developed. In Sec. V, we discuss the applications of our theory.

For the noninteracting case, the states in the set â„›â‰¡{|Ïˆjâ€‹(ğ¤)âŸ©}j=1,â‹¯,nâ„›subscriptketsubscriptğœ“ğ‘—ğ¤ğ‘—1â‹¯ğ‘›\mathcal{R}\equiv\{|\psi_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle\}_{j=1,\cdots,n} are orthogonal to each other, and Eq.â€‰(4) is invariant under a Uâ€‹(n)ğ‘ˆğ‘›U(n) transformation for |ÏˆjâŸ©ketsubscriptğœ“ğ‘—|\psi_{j}\rangle in â„›â„›\mathcal{R} (see Appendix B). IV Density-matrix description

For weak coupling and the noninteracting case, the blind bands are always close to the new poles. This property allows us to smoothly tune Îµjâ€‹(ğ¤)subscriptğœ€ğ‘—ğ¤\varepsilon_{j}(\mathbf{k}) for a well-defined GAâ€‹(ğ¤,Ï‰)subscriptğºğ´ğ¤ğœ”G_{A}(\mathbf{k},\omega), avoiding bands or blind bands crossing the zero point, so that the first nğ‘›n poles [Îµjâ€‹(ğ¤)<0subscriptğœ€ğ‘—ğ¤0\varepsilon_{j}(\mathbf{k})<0] are moved together to ÎµGâ€‹(ğ¤)<0subscriptğœ€ğºğ¤0\varepsilon_{G}(\mathbf{k})<0, and the others are moved to ÎµEâ€‹(ğ¤)>0subscriptğœ€ğ¸ğ¤0\varepsilon_{E}(\mathbf{k})>0, without changing the topological index (1). The topological Hamiltonian for the final Greenâ€™s function GÂ¯Aâ€‹(ğ¤,iâ€‹Ï‰)subscriptÂ¯ğºğ´ğ¤ğ‘–ğœ”\underline{G}_{A}(\mathbf{k},i\omega) is HÂ¯Atopo=[ÎµEâˆ’1â€‹ğˆAâˆ’xâ€‹ÏA]âˆ’1superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ»ğ´toposuperscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ¸1subscriptğˆğ´ğ‘¥subscriptğœŒğ´1\underline{H}_{A}^{\text{topo}}=[\varepsilon_{E}^{-1}\mathbf{I}_{A}-x\rho_{A}]^{-1}, where x=ÎµEâˆ’1âˆ’ÎµGâˆ’1>0ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğœ€ğ¸1superscriptsubscriptğœ€ğº10x=\varepsilon_{E}^{-1}-\varepsilon_{G}^{-1}>0. For the interacting case, using the Lehmann representation of the Greenâ€™s function GAsubscriptğºğ´G_{A} and by properly tuning the position of the many-body eigenenergy, a similar discussion can be applied and the same conclusion can be obtained (see Appendix D).

For strong coupling, the blind bands may cross the zero point even for a gapped system, in which case the Chern number (1) becomes ill defined. To extend the concept of the topological index to a general gapped system, we propose the following formula as a generalized topological index:

IA=âˆ‘j=1mÎµÎ±â€‹Î²2â€‹Ï€â€‹iâ€‹âˆ«d2â€‹kâ€‹âŸ¨âˆ‚Î±ÏˆÂ¯jâ€‹(ğ¤)|âˆ‚Î²ÏˆÂ¯jâ€‹(ğ¤)âŸ©,subscriptğ¼ğ´superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘šsuperscriptğœ€ğ›¼ğ›½2ğœ‹ğ‘–superscriptğ‘‘2ğ‘˜inner-productsubscriptğ›¼subscriptÂ¯ğœ“ğ‘—ğ¤subscriptğ›½subscriptÂ¯ğœ“ğ‘—ğ¤{I}_{A}=\sum_{j=1}^{m}\frac{\varepsilon^{\alpha\beta}}{2\pi i}\int d^{2}k\langle\partial_{\alpha}\overline{\psi}_{j}(\mathbf{k})|\partial_{\beta}\overline{\psi}_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle, (6)

where |ÏˆÂ¯jâ€‹(ğ¤)âŸ©ketsubscriptÂ¯ğœ“ğ‘—ğ¤|\overline{\psi}_{j}(\mathbf{k})\rangle are the eigenstates of ÏAâ€‹(ğ¤)subscriptğœŒğ´ğ¤\rho_{A}(\mathbf{k}) with the mğ‘šm largest eigenvalues. From the above discussion, for the weak-coupling case, we have IA=ChAsubscriptğ¼ğ´subscriptChğ´{I}_{A}=\text{Ch}_{A}. Moreover, formula (6) is the same as the definition of topology for a â€˜density matrixâ€™ inâ€‰ Bardyn2013njp ; Budich2015prb . For the strong-coupling case with a well-defined ChAsubscriptChA\rm{Ch}_{A}, these two quantities may be different, if the system in this phase region cannot be mapped to an isolated system by smoothly changing (without the blind bands and the energy spectrum crossing the zero point) the parameters such as the coupling strength.

Without interaction and without coupling to the environment, the eigenvalues of ÏAsubscriptğœŒğ´\rho_{A} are 111 (with degeneracy mğ‘šm) and 00, which gives the gapped flat-band structure. The interaction and coupling will change the single-particle distribution, and the null eigenvalues become finite. However, the mğ‘šm majority eigenstates are still gapped from the minority eigenstates. The topological phase transition occurs when the mğ‘šmth largest eigenvalue of ÏAâ€‹(ğ¤)subscriptğœŒğ´ğ¤\rho_{A}(\mathbf{k}) becomes degenerate with the (m+1)ğ‘š1(m+1)th largest eigenvalue of ÏAâ€‹(ğ¤)subscriptğœŒğ´ğ¤\rho_{A}(\mathbf{k}) or the gap of the energy spectrum closes (which may lead to an energy band inversion for GAsubscriptğºğ´G_{A} and thus a sudden change in the eigenstates of ÏAsubscriptğœŒğ´\rho_{A}). In contrast, by the definition of the Chern number (1), the topological phase transition can occur when the blind bands close and reopen a gap between them without any energy band inversionâ€‰Gurarie2011prb .

V Applications

V.1 Z2subscriptğ‘2Z_{2} topological invariant

For a time-reversal (ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T})-invariant 2D system, the Z2subscriptğ‘2{Z}_{2} topological index in the form of a Greenâ€™s function is a five-dimensional integralâ€‰Wang2010prl . For the case with conserved spin, the Z2subscriptğ‘2{Z}_{2} index Î½ğœˆ\nu can be expressed through the topological index of the decoupled spin subsystem [see Eq.â€‰(1)], i.e., Î½=Châ†‘â€‹modâ€‹2ğœˆsubscriptChâ†‘mod2\nu=\text{Ch}_{\uparrow}~{}\text{mod}~{}2 Kane2005prl ; Hohenadler2013jpcm ; Wu2006prl ; Xu2006prb , which simplifies the calculation greatly. Here, the Chern number ChÏƒsubscriptChğœ\text{Ch}_{\sigma} reflects the number of edge states for each spin. The spin conservation can be violated by different types of spin-orbit coupling (SOC)â€‰Kane2005prl . In the following, we point out that for the weak SOC case, Î½=Châ†‘â€‹modâ€‹2ğœˆsubscriptChâ†‘mod2\nu=\text{Ch}_{\uparrow}~{}\text{mod}~{}2, and for a general gapped case, Î½=Iâ†‘â€‹modâ€‹2ğœˆsubscriptğ¼â†‘mod2\nu={I}_{\uparrow}~{}\text{mod}~{}2, relating the topology of the subsystem and that of the full system Prodan2009prb ; Fukui2014jpsj .

Let Gâ†‘subscriptğºâ†‘G_{\uparrow} and Gâ†“subscriptğºâ†“G_{\downarrow} be the Greenâ€™s functions for each spin subsystem. Due to ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} symmetry, we have the following relations (see Appendix C): Gâ†‘âˆ—â€‹(ğ¤,iâ€‹Ï‰)=Gâ†“â€‹(âˆ’ğ¤,âˆ’iâ€‹Ï‰)superscriptsubscriptğºâ†‘ğ¤ğ‘–ğœ”subscriptğºâ†“ğ¤ğ‘–ğœ”G_{\uparrow}^{*}(\mathbf{k},i\omega)=G_{\downarrow}(-\mathbf{k},-i\omega), Ïâ†‘âˆ—â€‹(ğ¤)=Ïâ†“â€‹(âˆ’ğ¤)superscriptsubscriptğœŒâ†‘ğ¤subscriptğœŒâ†“ğ¤\rho_{\uparrow}^{*}(\mathbf{k})=\rho_{\downarrow}(-\mathbf{k}), and Gâ†‘â€‹(ğ¤,Ï‰+iâ€‹Î´)=Gâ†“Tâ€‹(âˆ’ğ¤,Ï‰+iâ€‹Î´)subscriptğºâ†‘ğ¤ğœ”ğ‘–ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğºâ†“ğ‘‡ğ¤ğœ”ğ‘–ğ›¿G_{\uparrow}(\mathbf{k},\omega+i\delta)=G_{\downarrow}^{T}(-\mathbf{k},\omega+i\delta). The first two relations imply Châ†‘=âˆ’Châ†“subscriptChâ†‘subscriptChâ†“\text{Ch}_{\uparrow}=-\text{Ch}_{\downarrow} and Iâ†‘=âˆ’Iâ†“subscriptğ¼â†‘subscriptğ¼â†“{I}_{\uparrow}=-{I}_{\downarrow} from Eqs.â€‰(1) andâ€‰(6). The last relation shows a close relation between the density of state for each subsystem, which indicates that the subsystems and the full system close and reopen a gap at the same time. The topological state for the full system is changed when the topological properties in the subsystem are changed due to the SOC coupling to the other subsystem. Thus, the Z2subscriptğ‘2Z_{2} index can be obtained from the index IAsubscriptğ¼ğ´I_{A} of the subsystem.

In Fig.â€‰3 in appendix C, we plot the numerical results for the topological index IAsubscriptğ¼ğ´{I}_{A} of the subsystem of the Kane-Mele model, showing the exact relation to the Z2subscriptğ‘2{Z}_{2} index, Î½=Iâ†‘â€‹modâ€‹2ğœˆsubscriptğ¼â†‘mod2\nu={I}_{\uparrow}~{}\text{mod}~{}2.

V.2 Proximity effect

A simple but fundamental question is what happens when an ordinary insulator is coupled to a topological insulator. As an example, here we consider a system on a bi-layer honeycomb lattice, with each layer described by the Haldane modelâ€‰Haldane1988prl : HÎ±=[âˆ’t1âˆ‘âŸ¨i,jâŸ©ciâ€‹Î±â€ cjâ€‹Î±âˆ’t2âˆ‘âŸ¨âŸ¨i,jâŸ©âŸ©eiâ€‹Î¸â€‹Ï•Î±ciâ€‹Î±â€ cjâ€‹Î±+H.c.]+mÎ±âˆ‘i(âˆ’1)iciâ€‹Î±â€ ciâ€‹Î±H_{\alpha}=[-t_{1}\sum_{\langle i,j\rangle}c_{i\alpha}^{\dagger}c_{j\alpha}-t_{2}\sum_{\langle\langle i,j\rangle\rangle}e^{i\theta\phi_{\alpha}}c_{i\alpha}^{\dagger}c_{j\alpha}+{\rm H.c.}]+m_{\alpha}\sum_{i}(-1)^{i}c_{i\alpha}^{\dagger}c_{i\alpha}, where t1subscriptğ‘¡1t_{1} is the nearest-neighbor tunneling, t2subscriptğ‘¡2t_{2} is the next-nearest-neighbor tunneling with a phase Î¸â€‹Ï•Î±ğœƒsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ›¼\theta\phi_{\alpha} and Î¸=Â±1ğœƒplus-or-minus1\theta=\pm 1, mÎ±subscriptğ‘šğ›¼m_{\alpha} is the staggered potential, and Î±=1,2ğ›¼12\alpha=1,2 is the layer index. The parameters are t1=4â€‹t2subscriptğ‘¡14subscriptğ‘¡2t_{1}=4t_{2}, Ï•1=Ï€/2subscriptitalic-Ï•1ğœ‹2\phi_{1}=\pi/2, m1=0subscriptğ‘š10m_{1}=0, Ï•2=0subscriptitalic-Ï•20\phi_{2}=0, and m2=0.2â€‹t2subscriptğ‘š20.2subscriptğ‘¡2m_{2}=0.2t_{2}, so that the first layer is a Chern insulator, and the second one is an ordinary insulator.

To observe the interference effect, we further introduce a tunneling term between layers, H12=t12â€‹âˆ‘iciâ€‹2â€ â€‹ciâ€‹1+H.cformulae-sequencesubscriptğ»12subscriptğ‘¡12subscriptğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–2â€ subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1HcH_{12}=t_{12}\sum_{i}c_{i2}^{\dagger}c_{i1}+\rm{H.c}. The topological index IAsubscriptIğ´\text{I}_{A} with respect to the tunneling coefficient t12subscriptğ‘¡12t_{12} is shown in Fig.â€‰2a. In the whole region of t12/t2subscriptğ‘¡12subscriptğ‘¡2t_{12}/t_{2}, the index IAsubscriptğ¼ğ´I_{A} for the first layer is unchanged. For the second layer, there are no edge modes or edge blind bands when t12=0subscriptğ‘¡120t_{12}=0. For a small finite t12subscriptğ‘¡12t_{12}, since the full system has gapless poles on the edge, the second layer also has a gapless edge state and simultaneously a gapless blind state appear. The Chern number ChA=IAsubscriptChğ´subscriptğ¼ğ´\text{Ch}_{A}={I}_{A} is still zero, like as the new bulk-boundary correspondence we claimed. The second layer subsystem obtains a nonzero topological index when t12â‰³0.83â€‹t2greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptğ‘¡120.83subscriptğ‘¡2t_{12}\gtrsim 0.83t_{2}, while the full system displays a transition from a Chern insulator to a trivial one through band inversion. For t12â‰³0.83â€‹t2greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptğ‘¡120.83subscriptğ‘¡2t_{12}\gtrsim 0.83t_{2}, the stable edge state disappears, but the gapless blind band remains, and thus, IA=âˆ’1subscriptğ¼ğ´1I_{A}=-1 for the second layer. For t12=2.5â€‹t2subscriptğ‘¡122.5subscriptğ‘¡2t_{12}=2.5t_{2}, the spectrum of the full system with zigzag edges is shown in Fig.â€‰2(b), which has no edge states. However, the spectrum of the density matrix for each layer contains a gapless edge state, which is shown in Fig.â€‰2(c). For the second layer, the blind bands become gapless at the edge [Fig.â€‰2(d)].

VI Conclusion

We have systemically discussed the topology of 2D open systems. The invariant given by the Ishikawa-Matsuyama formula reflects the number difference of gapless edge modes and gapless edge blind bands. Moreover, we defined another topological invariant in terms of the single-particle density matrix which is applicable for general gapped systems and is equivalent to the former invariant for the case of weak coupling to the environment. Two applications were discussed. For time-reversal invariant insulators, we explained that the relation of the Chern invariant for each spin subsystem and the Z2subscriptğ‘2{Z}_{2} index of the full system is given by Î½=Iâ†‘â€‹modâ€‹2ğœˆsubscriptğ¼â†‘mod2\nu={I}_{\uparrow}~{}\text{mod}~{}2, which highly simplifies the calculation for the Z2subscriptğ‘2{Z}_{2} index. In addition, we consider the proximity effect when an ordinary insulator is coupled to a topological insulator, which shows an inverse topological invariant is induced by the nontrivial part Hsieh2016prl .

The examples given here are for non-interacting cases. The method can be applied to the interacting system, also at finite temperature, and the single-particle density matrix can be obtained, for example, by using dynamical mean-field theory.

The only difference from Eqs.â€‰(11) and (12) is the sign, which explains the result [eq.(3)] in the main text.

Appendix C Time-reversal-invariant system
